content:
Yes, you can execute the updated Apex script in the Developer Console's "Execute Anonymous" window. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to do this:

1. Open the Developer Console in your Salesforce instance. To do this, click on the gear icon in the upper right corner of the Salesforce interface and select "Developer Console" from the menu.
2. In the Developer Console, click on the "Debug" menu in the top toolbar and select "Open Execute Anonymous Window" or press Ctrl+E (Cmd+E on Mac).
3. Copy and paste the updated Apex script provided in the previous response into the "Enter Apex Code" text area in the "Execute Anonymous" window.
4. (Optional) Check the "Open Log" checkbox at the bottom of the "Execute Anonymous" window to automatically open the debug log after the script is executed.
5. Click the "Execute" button at the bottom right corner of the "Execute Anonymous" window to run the script.
6. After the script has finished running, you can view the debug log by going to the "Logs" tab at the bottom of the Developer Console. If you checked the "Open Log" checkbox, the log should open automatically. Otherwise, you can double-click the latest log to open it.
7. In the debug log, look for the lines that start with "USER\_DEBUG" to view the script's output. The top 5 hours with the highest contact count will be displayed in these lines.

By following these steps, you can execute the updated Apex script in the Developer Console's "Execute Anonymous" window and view the results in the debug log.
